newsitem.title: USA: Wall Data shares plunge on earnings outlook, lawsuit.
newsitem.headline: Wall Data shares plunge on earnings outlook, lawsuit.

text.p: Wall Data Inc. shares fell as much as 38 percent Tuesday after the software company said it expects to report second-quarter earnings just half of what Wall Street expected.
Wall Data also said Monday it will pay $11.25 million to settle a shareholder lawsuit, an amount that raised concerns among some investors about the company's integrity.
On top of that, the Kirkland, Wash.-based company unexpectedly announced that Chairman and Chief Executive Jim Simpson, 58, will retire at the end of the month.

Stock in Wall Data was down $9.125 at $18.625 on Nasdaq in midday trading of more than 3 million shares, making the stock one of the most active in U.S. markets and one of the biggest percentage losers on Nasdaq. Earlier, the stock traded as low as $17.25.

Wall Data specialises in software that connects networks of personal computers to mainframes, a niche that was growing explosively until a few years ago. But increasingly, companies are using cheap Internet browsers from companies such as Netscape Communications Corp. and Microsoft Corp. to tap information stored on mainframes.

"It's getting very easy to make that connection" between PCs and mainframes, undercutting the price of expensive networking products like Wall Data's Rumba, said Eric Brown, senior analyst at market researcher Forrester Research Inc.

After the market closed Monday, Wall Data said it expected to report earnings, before charges, of 17 to 20 cents a share for the quarter ended June 30. Analysts expected Wall Data to earn 34 cents a share, according to a recent survey by Zacks Investment Research.

Second-quarter revenue will be about $35.5 million, compared with $34.8 million in the same quarter a year ago, the company said. Rob Owens, analyst at brokerage Pacific Crest Securities, said revenue in the most recent quarter will be about $3 million less than he expected.
Wall Data said it is taking longer for it to sell its products because customers are taking their time evaluating how to deal with the Internet.

The company also said it will take a $10.7 million charge in the second quarter mostly to cover the cost of settling a shareholder lawsuit filed two years ago. The lawsuit was filed shortly after Wall Data announced another earnings shortfall and suffered a huge stock drop.
Under terms of the settlement, Wall Data will pay $11.25 million to the plaintiff. The company's insurance will pay $3 million of that amount. Wall Data will pay the balance with cash on hand.
The size of the settlement raised concerns among some investors.
"Normally these things get settled for a paltry amount," not millions, said one investor.

But company Chief Financial Officer Richard Van Hoesen said the settlement was not unusual. "We were spending $100,000 a month on this. It was a huge burden on management," he said, adding that it was better to settle than to continue fighting.
